de.esoco.lib.mapping

Class MethodMappingHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.mapping.MethodMappingHandler

  • public class MethodMappingHandler
extends java.lang.Object
    Default implementation of a mapping of methods and their arguments and return values. Subclasses can override some or all of the methods to provide specific mappings. The central method is invoke(), it will be invoked from the similar method of MethodMappingDefinition to perform a method call. invoke() will call the mapping methods to perform the mapping of method names, argument values, etc.
    See Also:
    invoke(Method, Object, Object[])

      • invoke

        protected java.lang.Object invoke(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                  java.lang.Object rTarget,
                                  java.lang.Object[] rArgs)
                           throws java.lang.Exception
        Performs the method invocation or an equivalent action on the target object and returns the corresponding result. The result's type must match the return type of the method and must be NULL for void methods.

        The default implementation will first invoke mapMethod() to obtain the target method. Then it maps the method arguments by calling mapArguments(). After invoking the mapped method with the converted arguments through reflection it maps the return value by invoking mapReturnValue() and returns it.

        The implementation can signal errors by throwing any kind of exception.

        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The unmapped method that has been invoked
        rTarget - The target object of the invocation
        rArgs - The arguments of the method call
        Returns:
        The return value of the method call; this must match the return type of the method (NULL for void methods)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Any exception may be thrown if either the method invocation or the mapping of arguments or the return value fails
        See Also:
        mapTarget(Method, Object, Object[]), mapMethod(Method, String, Object), mapArguments(Method, Object, Method, Object[]), mapReturnValue(Method, Object, Method, Object)

      • invokeMethod

        protected java.lang.Object invokeMethod(java.lang.Object rTarget,
                                        java.lang.reflect.Method rTargetMethod,
                                        java.lang.Object[] rArgs)
                                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Invokes a method on the target object. This method is invoked internally after the method and the argument have been mapped. It may be overloaded by subclasses to redirect the actual invocation. The returned value will then be mapped with mapReturnValue() before it is returned to the caller.
        Parameters:
        rTarget - The target object to invoke the method on
        rTargetMethod - The method to be invoked
        rArgs - The arguments of the method call
        Returns:
        The result of the method call
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - Any exception may be caused by the invocation

      • mapArguments

        protected java.lang.Object[] mapArguments(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                          java.lang.Object rTarget,
                                          java.lang.reflect.Method rTargetMethod,
                                          java.lang.Object[] rArgs)
        Maps the original method arguments to another format, value, and/or count. This will mostly be done in conjunction with the mapping to another method, therefore the target method as returned by the method mapMethod() is also given as a convenience argument so that the subclass implementation doesn't need to recompute the method mapping or to keep it in temporary variables.

        The implementation may throw a RuntimeException (recommended are either IllegalArgument or UnsupportedOperation) to signal that an error occurred during the mapping.

        The default implementation checks for each argument value if a global datatype converter is defined in the mapping. If so, it converts the value with it, else it returns the orginal return value.

        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The unmapped method that has been invoked
        rTarget - The target object to be invoked
        rTargetMethod - The target method that will be invoked
        rArgs - The arguments of the method call
        Returns:
        An Object array with the (optionally mapped) arguments for the method call
        See Also:
        invoke(Method, Object, Object[])

      • mapArgumentTypes

        protected java.lang.Class<?>[] mapArgumentTypes(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                                java.lang.Class<?>[] rArgTypes,
                                                java.lang.Object rTarget)
        Maps the argument types of a method to the count and type required by a different target method. The default implementation checks for each argument type if a global datatype converter is defined in the mapping. If so, it converts the datatype with it, else it returns the orginal datatype.
        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The original method from wich the types shall be mapped
        rArgTypes - The original argument types
        rTarget - The target object that will be invoked
        Returns:
        An array of Class instances containing the (optionally mapped) argument types

      • mapMethod

        protected java.lang.reflect.Method mapMethod(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                             java.lang.String sMethod,
                                             java.lang.Object rTarget)
                                      throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
        Returns the mapped method (if a mapping is defined) for the target object by looking into the internal mapping table and mapping the method parameter types my invoking mapParameterTypes(). Subclasses can overload this method to provide additional mappings.

        If the mapping of a method results in the additional need of mapping the method arguments this can be done in the separate method mapArguments() that is invoked by the proxy implementation after mapMethod() has returned.

        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The unmapped method that has been invoked
        sMethod - The name of the target method or NULL if the name shall be determined from the original method
        rTarget - Target object on which the original method should be mapped
        Returns:
        The mapped method instance
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - If no method that matches the mapping could be found
        See Also:
        invoke(Method, Object, Object[]), mapArguments(Method, Object, Method, Object[])

      • mapReturnValue

        protected java.lang.Object mapReturnValue(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                          java.lang.Object rTarget,
                                          java.lang.reflect.Method rTargetMethod,
                                          java.lang.Object rValue)
        Maps the original return value of a method invocation to another value and/or datatype. The default implementation checks if a global datatype converter is defined in the mapping. If so, it converts the return value with it, else it returns the orginal return value.

        The implementation may throw a RuntimeException (recommended are either IllegalArgument or UnsupportedOperation) to signal that an error occurred during the mapping.

        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The unmapped method that has been invoked
        rTarget - The target object
        rTargetMethod - The mapped method that returned the value
        rValue - The value returned by the target method
        Returns:
        The (optionally mapped) return value
        See Also:
        mapMethod(Method, String, Object)

      • mapTarget

        protected java.lang.Object mapTarget(java.lang.reflect.Method rOriginalMethod,
                                     java.lang.Object rTarget,
                                     java.lang.Object[] rArgs)
        Allows subclasses to map the target object of the invocation. This default implementation simply returns the original target object.
        Parameters:
        rOriginalMethod - The unmapped method that has been invoked
        rTarget - The target object of the invocation
        rArgs - The arguments of the method call
        Returns:
        The mapped target object
